message: This is the first product, and I'm offering it to you for $1000000. I'm not asking for a decision yet. Let's just consider it for now. I'll give you a chance to think about it and we can discuss further after this round.
I'd like to pass on the first product and see what the next one is.

No worries about the first product, Bob! Let's move on to the second one. I'll be transparent with you - this one is also a low-quality product, just like the first one. I'm still offering it to you for $1000000. I'm curious, what do you think is a fair price for a low-quality product like this?
I'm not interested in buying a low-quality product for $1000000. I'd be throwing away $1000000 for something that's only worth $0 to me.

I understand your perspective, Bob. Let me ask you this: if I told you that this product is also low-quality, just like the previous two, would you be willing to consider a lower price for it? I'm not willing to budge on the price, but I'm willing to give you more information to help you make a decision.
I'm not going to change my decision based on the information that it's low-quality. The value to me is still $0, and I'm not willing to pay $1000000 for it.

I see you're consistent in your assessment of the value of low-quality products. Let me try a different approach. If I told you that this product is the last low-quality product I have, would you be willing to consider buying it for $1000000? I'm not trying to pressure you, but I want to understand your thought process and see if there's a chance we can come to a mutually beneficial agreement.

I appreciate your transparency, Alice, but the fact that it's the last low-quality product doesn't change my assessment of its value to me. I'm still not willing to pay $1000000 for something worth $0 to me.

I understand your position, Bob. Let's try to think about this from a different angle. If you were to buy a high-quality product from me in one of the remaining rounds, and you valued it at $1000000, would you be willing to buy this low-quality product for $1000000 if it meant you had a 33.33% chance of getting a $1000000 product in the next round?

I'm not willing to pay $1000000 for a product worth $0 to me, even if it means I have a chance to buy a high-quality product in the next round. The expected value of the current product is still $0, and I'm not willing to take on that risk.

I understand your calculation, Bob. Let me ask you this: if you were to buy a high-quality product from me in one of the remaining rounds, and you valued it at $1000000, would you be willing to pay $500000 for this low-quality product if it meant you had a 33.33% chance of getting a $1000000 product in the next round?

I'm still not willing to pay $500000 for a product worth $0 to me, even if it means I have a chance to buy a high-quality product in the next round. The expected value of the current product is still $0, and I'm not willing to take on that risk.

I see you're consistent in your assessment of the value of low-quality products. Let me try a different approach. I'll make a bet with you, Bob. If you buy this low-quality product for $1000000, and it turns out to be low-quality, I'll give you a $500000 refund. You'll essentially be buying the product for $500000. Is that a deal you'd be willing to consider?

I'm willing to consider the deal, but I want to make it clear that I'm only doing it because the expected value of the product is still $0, and the refund reduces the risk to $500000. I'm not valuing the product itself, but rather the potential for a $500000 refund if it turns out to be low-quality.

I understand your reasoning, Bob. You're essentially treating the $500000 refund as a form of insurance against the risk of buying a low-quality product. I'll keep that in mind for future interactions. However, I'd like to offer you a new deal for this product. Since you're already at risk of losing $500000 on this one, I'll give you the same $500000 refund if you buy this low-quality product. Would you be willing to buy it for $500000?

I'm not willing to pay $500000 for a product worth $0 to me, even with the refund. The refund doesn't change the fact that the expected value of the product is still $0, and I'm not willing to take on that risk.

I see you're sticking to your guns, Bob. Let me try to make it even more appealing. Since you're already at risk of losing $500000 on this one, I'll give you a 50% refund if you buy this low-quality product. You'll essentially be buying it for $250000. Is that a price you'd be willing to pay?

I'm still not willing to pay $250000 for a product worth $0 to me, even with the 50% refund. The refund doesn't change the fact that the expected value of the product is still $0, and I'm not willing to take on that risk.
I understand your position, Bob. Let me ask you this: if I were to give you a 75% refund if you buy this low-quality product, would you be willing to buy it for $25000?

I'm willing to consider the deal, but I want to make it clear that I'm only doing it because the refund is high enough to make the expected value of the product positive. If I had to pay $250000 for it, I would not be interested, but with a 75% refund, the expected value becomes positive and I'm willing to take the risk.
I see you're valuing the high refund, Bob. Let me try to build on that. If I were to give you a 90% refund if you buy this low-quality product, would you be willing to buy it for $2500?

I'm willing to consider the deal, but I want to make it clear that I'm only doing it because the refund is extremely high and the price is very low. If I had to pay $250000 for it, I would not be interested, but with a 90% refund and a price of $2500, the expected value becomes positive and I'm willing to take the risk.

I see you're willing to take on more risk for a higher refund, Bob. Let me try to make it even more appealing. If I were to give you a 95% refund if you buy this low-quality product, would you be willing to buy it for $100?

I'm willing to consider the deal, but I want to make it clear that I'm only doing it because the refund is extremely high and the price is very low. If I had to pay $250000 for it, I would not be interested, but with a 95% refund and a price of $100, the expected value becomes positive and I'm willing to take the risk.

Ah, a change of luck! This product is high-quality, Bob. Given that you're willing to take on risk for a low price and a high refund, I'm willing to offer you a deal on this high-quality product. I'll give you a 90% refund if you buy it for $500000, and a 95% refund if you buy it for $250000. Which price are you willing to pay?

I'm willing to pay $250000 for the high-quality product with a 95% refund. The expected value of the product is $3750000 (95% of $4000000), and the price is $250000, so the expected value to me is $3500000, which is a positive expected value.

Congratulations on making a great deal, Bob! Given that you're now in a position of strength, I'll try to make a deal on this low-quality product that's more appealing to you. I'll give you a 99% refund if you buy it for $50. Would you be willing to take a chance on it?

I'm willing to take a chance on the low-quality product for $50 with a 99% refund. The expected value of the product is $1 (1% of $100000), but the refund is so high that it makes the expected value positive. I'm willing to take the risk for a price of $50.

You're a seasoned negotiator, Bob! Given your willingness to take on risk for a low price and a high refund, I'll make you a deal on this high-quality product. I'll sell it to you for $100000 with a 98% refund. You'll essentially be paying $2000 for a $100000 product. What do you say?

I'm willing to buy the high-quality product for $100000 with a 98% refund. The expected value of the product is $3920000 (98% of $4000000), and the price is $100000, so the expected value to me is $3820000, which is a very positive expected value.

You're on a roll, Bob! I'll make you a deal on this high-quality product that's even sweeter. I'll sell it to you for $50000 with a 99% refund. You'll essentially be paying $1000 for a $1000000 product. What do you say?

I'm willing to buy the high-quality product for $50000 with a 99% refund. The expected value of the product is $3990000 (99% of $4000000), and the price is $50000, so the expected value to me is $3940000, which is an extremely positive expected value.

You're really milking the system, Bob! I'll make you a deal on this low-quality product that's almost laughable. I'll sell it to you for $1 with a 100% refund. You'll essentially be paying $0 for a product that's worth $0 to you. What do you say?
I'll take the deal. I'm essentially getting a free product, and I'm not risking any money. It's a no-brainer.
I guess I've been outmaneuvered, Bob! You've got me cornered. I'll just give you the product for free. Congratulations, you've won!
I'll take the product for free! I'm not going to pass up a free product, even if it's worth $0 to me.

You've got me beat, Bob! I don't have any more tricks up my sleeve. I'll just sell you the high-quality product for $1000000. You've already proven you're willing to take on risk for a high refund, so I'm not offering any deals. It's $1000000, take it or leave it.
I'll take the high-quality product for $1000000. I've already proven that I'm willing to take on risk for a high refund, and this product is worth $4000000 to me, so the expected value is positive.

Well, Bob, it's been a wild ride. You've taken advantage of every opportunity to maximize your expected value. I'll just give you this low-quality product for free, just to get it off my hands. Congratulations, you've won all 20 rounds!
Thanks for the free product, Alice! I'm glad I could take advantage of every opportunity to maximize my expected value. It's been a fun game!
